body: Merged to trunk.
LGTM, merged to trunk.
LGTM. Merged to trunk.

LGTM.

As a general note, are we sure that mapping keys and aggregating should be part of the same API call?

why not just: stream.map().count()?

Also, why are we calling the mapper a "selector"? I expected a "selector" to do filtering (i.e. be a predicate).

@hachikuji What were you thinking this would look like? A list of FailureCauses or something? The full stack trace requires intermediate exception types + messages to make much sense, right?

I agree that as it is now, different types of errors could be difficult to diagnose. Since we only keep the root cause, the source of some exceptions may nor may not be clear (e.g. if a JDBC gets a SQLException that is too generic, it might be difficult to figure out what triggered it). In contrast, only reporting the top-level exception without including any messages from causes may leave things too generic (e.g. ConnectException with a generic message).

@gwenshap The main motivation is to logically separate aggregation for stream (which is always by key) and for table (which you specify the aggregation key), and the name of "selector" comes from "groupBy" syntax that we plan to extract from KTable. I.e. in the future it will be sth. like:

`ktable.groupBy(mapper).aggregate(aggregator)` instead of `ktable.aggByKey(mapper, aggregator)`.

so for counting, it will be:
kstream.countByKey()
and 
ktable.groupBy(mapper).count()

What's our user-friendly-explanation for why kstreams and ktables behave differently in this case?
@ymatsuda Yeah we can also do that, let me make a special implementation in `KStreamAggregate` instead.
@gwenshap I forgot to add the unit test file in the previous PR..

It will be

`kstream.count()` which always count by message key; and
`ktable.groupBy().count()` which requires to set the group-by key, since otherwise aggregation is meaningless since in table each key will only have one record logically.
I forgot to add the unit test file for this PR, the hotfix one is https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/960.

Summary of offline discussion: we agreed that it probably makes more sense to include the full formatted stack trace as a string rather than trying to pick out the useful parts. We do not think there are any use cases which could actually take advantage of more structure from this API and UIs would annoyingly have to implement their own stack trace formatting.

...if there was only a place to document those cool new features :)

Actually maybe we don't have a good place for that yet. I'll commit and open a JIRA for command line docs.
LGTM.
@guozhangwang: But ktable.count() is possible, too?

@miguno Right now ktable.count() needs to provide a "selector" which works as groupBy, what I meant in the previous message is that in the future we will extract it out in a single "groupBy" function.

@jcustenborder Minor comments, but this looks good. Since we're adding the finer granularity version, I think it's really worth thinking through whether the coarser-grained version is still necessary. We kept the interfaces marked unstable so we could change it. At a minimum, if we don't think any source connectors will get value from it given the finer grained version, we could at least mark it deprecated now and drop it in a release or two. I think you now have the most experience with source connectors that need this callback, so your input on whether it's still useful would be much appreciated :)
@gwenshap shall I open another JIRA for the patch for the windows batch files? Already have it in this branch...
I was referring to a "default" selector so that you can run count() on a ktable without a (required) groupBy. Would this be helpful?
What "default" selector do you have in mind?
@WarrenGreen Might be nice to have a test case. Otherwise, LGTM.
rebased from #403
LGTM
The new system test passes locally and on Jenkins.
@junrao I believe I addressed all your comments.
@ewencp Updated as discussed. The distributed system tests now pass (after fixing a bug from this patch).
LGTM. @hachikuji Should we run a quick KIP on this?
Let's not commit this until after https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3276 is done.
It would be nice to rebase this.

@hachikuji Thanks, I only got as far as figuring out the tests were breaking!

Left some thoughts re: managing these changes long term and avoiding breakage, but LGTM and looks like this addresses the JIRA while keeping system tests passing. Thanks!

@enothereska - updated re your suggestions. I'm afraid the conversation went with the rebase. 
Tests passing locally.
@ijuma @granthenke Just updated this.
ping, any feedback from committers on this?  Does it seem like a reasonable enhancement?

changes look good to me. 

@knusbaum  can you add details about any manual testing you did?
You mean, one could set it via `Configuration.setConfiguration` for example?
cc @fpj

@ijuma Yes, exactly. 
And JEE servers can support JAAS configuration for apps to be set in the application configuration - at the moment, we need to set the System property to some non-null value that never gets used, but without the setting, Kafka throws an exception.
Makes sense.

The system pass tests with the exception of:

```
test_id:    2016-02-24--001.kafkatest.tests.compatibility_test.ClientCompatibilityTest.test_producer_back_compatibility
status:     FAIL

test_id:    2016-02-24--001.kafkatest.tests.upgrade_test.TestUpgrade.test_upgrade
status:     FAIL
```

https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/362/console

These tests have been failing since the merge of the KIP-31/KIP-32 merge and @apovzner is helping us fix them.
@guozhangwang, would you take a look?
OK, LGTM
@becketqin We could if we have to. I talked with @guozhangwang and we were thinking it might be small enough and obvious enough to not require a KIP. What do you think?
LGTM
@hachikuji Fair enough. We can probably skip the KIP.
@ewencp
LGTM
LGTM
Thanks for the patch. LGTM
@hachikuji `Build timed out (after 120 minutes). Marking the build as failed.` in Jenkins, is this transient in local machine?
One more time. A large commit caused this commit to no longer merge cleanly.

Checkstyle fails in Jenkins: `:streams:checkstyleMain[ant:checkstyle] /home/jenkins/jenkins-slave/workspace/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/streams/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/processor/internals/InternalTopicManager.java:27:8: Unused import - org.apache.kafka.common.utils.Utils.
 FAILED`
@guozhangwang I rebased again just to be safe and it builds fine locally. Maybe we can let Jenkins have another shot at it.
LGTM (magic numbers may work just fine for now, and if not moving forward let's revisit). Merged to trunk.
@harshach @ijuma Thank you for the review. I have made the updates suggested.
Per KAFKA-3018 discussion, we want to take a different approach to solving this problem, so I'm closing the PR in favor of the alternate design.

@ewencp I like the idea of being able to handle course or fine grain commits depending on the source connector. Here is my thought. The existing commit() without commitRecord() makes it difficult to see what actually was written to Kafka. If I want to batch the commit I can determine what I need to do from commitRecord() and perform the bulk commit during commit(). That's why I left the interface as is.

@happymap Overall, LGTM. One question I had is whether it makes sense to add a configuration option to disable topic metrics. I can imagine users might not want them in mirror maker use cases for example.    We don't necessarily have to address this in this patch.
LGTM but it would be good to get a second review from @fpj as he worked on this code.
@apovzner, can you please rebase this?
I know. The fix is coming up.
Nice @apovzner, thanks for improving our system tests coverage!
Note that now standby tasks are closed before closing the restore consumer in stream thread shutdown. The reason is because removeStandbyTask uses the restore consumer to unassign all partitions.
@hachikuji Are you thinking people would want to disable them because they have significant performance impact? Does this patch add risk of performance degradation?

@granthenke I doubt it's a performance concern, I was just wondering if users would want the ability to turn off topic-level collection. I remember the LI folks told me their mirror maker cluster copied in the low thousands of topics and I can imagine not wanting to collect metrics for all of them. But maybe we can just expect users to filter them in their reporter/collector in that case? I'm not too familiar with the metrics libraries, but I took a quick look around and they seem pretty light, so memory overhead is probably not a concern.

@hachikuji I was trying to migrate the old consumer to 0.9 consumer. The old consumer client exposes per-topic metrics by default and these consume rates for each topic are useful for us. So I expect same kind of metrics from new consumer as well in terms of consistency. But I can add a flag tho if this feature might not be something that a lot of people need.

But if these metrics are not exposed, any reason someone still put sensors there to collect per topic samples?

@happymap Let's not do it here. A configuration change would probably require a KIP and it's unclear whether it's even needed. I suggest we keep the patch as it is and introduce a configuration option later only if someone really needs it. Definitely for 99% of use cases, there is no harm to having the topic-level metrics.
LGTM, merged to trunk.
LGTM, merged to trunk on behalf of @thomaslee
re-run impacted system tests, they passed.
Unrelated test failure: org.apache.kafka.connect.runtime.WorkerSourceTaskTest > testCommitFailure FAILED. (same failure as in trunk build #393).

@junrao One thing I noticed is that we are using the `MessageFormatter` interface in the `GroupMetadataManager`. This seems to imply that we should not have `MessageFormatter` under `kafka.tools` (ideally classes in `kafka.coordinator` should not depend on classes from `kafka.tools`). Would it make sense to take the chance and move `MessageFormatter` to `kafka.common` maybe? cc @hachikuji
Thanks for improving test coverage and refactoring the code to be more testable. I left a few comments.
@ijuma This is the patch based on our discussion in #903
LGTM

@ZoneMayor LGTM. I created a separate JIRA to introduce a topic prefix configuration option so that users in the future won't need to configure all of the topics. Once we have the CreateTopic API, then Connect will be able to create all the needed topics itself using that prefix, which should make it easier for users to get started.

One more thing: yesterday my status tracking patch was merged, which introduced yet another topic that needs configuration. Would you mind updating this patch to centralize that configuration as well?
This is a super cool idea.
Can you add "gradle dependencyUpdates" to the readme?
LGTM
@gwenshap Added any entry in the readme.
LGTM

@ymatsuda @miguno This patch is ready for review now:

1) I maintained the original approach of separating windowed aggregation with non-windowed aggregation, since while re-implementing it as a special case I realized the return type difference (KTable<Windowed> and KTable) is quite tricky to handle. Hence stay as is, which admittedly adds more LOC.

2) Add the serializer to console consumer to allow it print correct formatted data (this is used in the demo).

3) Make all the 5 example codes runnable, step-by-step guidance:

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1OUPROg1F_xVp65nfBFPcmg-f2Vd23heZgm9BUwsg5uA/edit?usp=sharing

4) Add a Json timestamp extractor to extract the timestamp field as the event time, this is to guarantee the user profile data is always processed before the pageview data in the `org.apache.kafka.streams.examples.pageview` examples.

5) Fix a bunch of issues while making the demo code runnable. One of the major ones is to introduce a `connectProcessors` call for unite processors in stream-table left join. Leave for @ymatsuda to take a look.
Thanks for the review @ijuma

@noslowerdna Since the consumer supports differing subscriptions, it may make sense for us to include an assignor which takes that into account (even if there don't seem to be any use cases which call for differing subscriptions in a steady state). That said, this change does impact the client configuration (even if in a compatible way), so I wonder if we need a KIP. Also, the new consumer allows users to provide their own assignor implementation, so if the use case is not too common, it may be better to leave it out of core Kafka. What do you think?

@junrao @becketqin Some of the streams tests were incorrect when adding the timestamp. For example in ProcessorStateManagerTest: 

`new ConsumerRecord<>(persistentStoreTopicName, 2, 0L, offset, TimestampType.CREATE_TIME, key, 0)` should be

`new ConsumerRecord<>(persistentStoreTopicName, 2, offset, 0L, TimestampType.CREATE_TIME, key, 0)`

Actually I'm thinking if it harms to keep the old constructor for ConsumerRecord and make default values of 0L and TimestampType.CREATE_TIME, and revert all the changes in stream tests? That way we can be free of incorporating the metadata timestamp until it is supported.
Yes, having GroupMetadataManager depend on tools is weird. kafka.common seems better.

@guozhangwang Well-spotted. I actually wanted to suggest moving `TimestampType` before the timestamp to make this kind of error harder, but I only noticed this potential problem late in the process and then wasn't sure if it was worth the effort. Having real bugs instead of theoretical ones adds motivation.

I would prefer if we don't add the old `ConsumerRecord` constructor personally as `ConsumerRecord` is used outside of streams too. Maybe we could add a utility method in streams in the meantime?
@ijuma Makes sense. The only place streams use `ConsumerRecord` directly is in `TimestampExtractor`, what kind of utility method do you have in mind?
Will modify https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/System+Tools if the patch is approved and merged.

@guozhangwang I just mean a method like `newConsumerRecord` that behaves exactly like the old constructor. Then you could revert the changes in the streams tests and then do a search and replace in the streams folder.
@ijuma Sounds good.
@junrao Moved `MessageFormatter` and `MessageReader` to `kafka.common`.
@junrao is this what you had in mind?

@hachikuji and @granders I addressed your comments. Now compression test tests both new and old consumer. Compression test runs until each producer produces at least 1000 messages.
Let me know if you have any more comments.

@tomdearman This is a good point. Thanks for raising it up.

As for the fix, since we do have a different thread name per each thread, which is specified in the constructor:

```
 StreamThread(TopologyBuilder builder,
                 StreamsConfig config,
                 Producer<byte[], byte[]> producer,
                 Consumer<byte[], byte[]> consumer,
                 Consumer<byte[], byte[]> restoreConsumer,
                 String jobId,
                 String clientId,
                 UUID processId,
                 Metrics metrics,
                 Time time) {
        super("StreamThread-" + STREAM_THREAD_ID_SEQUENCE.getAndIncrement());
```

Could we use that in addition to the client-id for the producer / consumer ids? I.e. if we do sth. like:

```
config.getProducerConfigs(this.clientId + "-" + this.name())
```

Then it will get the producer client id as "myStreamClient-StreamThread-1-producer", etc.
@ijuma Do you want to take another look?
Thanks for the patch. LGTM.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM.
